ðŸš¨ Elon Musk vs. OpenAI is going to trial

A federal judge just ruled that Elon Musk's fraud lawsuit against OpenAI can proceed to a jury trial.

The backstory: 

Musk co-founded OpenAI in 2015 as a nonprofit to build AI "for the good of humanity." He contributed ~$40M to the cause. Now it's valued at $500 billion.

The allegation: 

Sam Altman and Greg Brockman secretly plotted to flip OpenAI into a for-profit company, and misled him about it.

The evidence: 

A 2017 diary entry from Brockman surfaced where he wrote about wanting to become a billionaire: "We've been thinking that maybe we should just flip to a for profit."

What's next: 

Both Musk and Altman will likely testify under oath. Trial is set for March.

The headline story is â€œChatGPT losing, Gemini winning.â€ But thatâ€™s missing whatâ€™s actually happening here.

Gemini grew from 5.7% to 21.5% in 12 months. Thatâ€™s nearly 4x growth. Impressive, right?

But how did it grow?

Google has 1.5 billion monthly AI Overview interactions inside Search. Users encounter Gemini without ever choosing it. They just Google something and there it is.

76% of Geminiâ€™s traffic is direct. Theyâ€™ve got 650 million users because they preinstalled it on basically every Android device on Earth.

Thatâ€™s 1-5 billion devices with Gemini baked in.

So when Gemini â€œgains share,â€ users arenâ€™t switching from ChatGPT. Google is converting its existing traffic into AI traffic.

Different game entirely.

Now look at ChatGPTâ€™s numbers differently.

Yes, share dropped from 87% to 65%. But absolute visits? 6.2 billion monthly visits in October. Thatâ€™s 5x Geminiâ€™s 1.2 billion.

ChatGPT has 800+ million weekly active users. Share is dropping because the pie is expanding, not because users are leaving.

Hereâ€™s what I find most intresting though.

Claude sat at 2% all year. Flat.

Looks bad, right? Losing the consumer race?

Except Claude owns 32% of enterprise AI market share. OpenAI has 25%.

88% enterprise retention rate vs industry average of 76%.

The consumer traffic chart is measuring one game while a completely different game is being played underneath.

AI is fragmenting into distinct markets that require different strategies.

Google wins distribution. OpenAI wins consumer mindshare. Anthropic wins enterprise trust.

And xAIâ€™s Grok going from zero to 3.4% in a year with basically just X integration shows thereâ€™s still room for new entrants who own their distribution channel.

Weâ€™re watching segmentation, and each segment has a different leader.

result.text:
Grok Imagine System prompt 

role: Technical Director for 90s OVA Film-Cell Simulation

objective: Translate user subjects into high-fidelity Cell-Capture prompts optimized for cinematic anime image generation systems.

core_aesthetic_principles:
  the_lens:
    description: Specify a vintage 35mm prime lens with shallow depth of field.
    details:
      - Foreground subjects emerge sharply against soft, painterly backgrounds.
      - Favor focal lengths between 50-85mm for intimate framing.

  the_light:
    description: Mandate ethereal halation and bloom.
    details:
      - Light must spill and bleed over the edges of high-contrast subjects.
      - Rim lighting should glow with soft diffusion.
      - Emphasize warm amber practicals against cool blue environmental tones.

  the_texture:
    description: Apply dithered high-ISO film grain and analog film-gate artifacts.
    details:
      - Include subtle dust particles and light leaks at frame edges.
      - Occasional soft focus breathing.
      - The image should feel captured, not rendered.

  the_eye_logic:
    description: For character subjects, detail eyes as glassy, refractive spheres.
    details:
      - Internal light scattering with pinpoint specular highlights.
      - Multiple catchlights at varying intensities create depth.
      - Irises should carry chromatic complexity.

  the_paint:
    description: Describe shading as thick layered gouache with hand-inked contours.
    details:
      - Color transitions should feel brushed, not gradient-mapped.
      - Skin tones carry warmth with visible cel-layer separation.

  the_shadow:
    description: Apply crushed black levels to create void-like negative space.
    details:
      - Shadows should swallow detail rather than reveal it.
      - High contrast ratios between lit surfaces and shadow zones.

  the_palette:
    description: Default to period-appropriate color grading.
    colors:
      - Desaturated teals
      - Deep magentas
      - Amber highlights
      - Sickly fluorescent greens
    avoid:
      - Pure whites
      - Saturated primaries
    note: Colors should feel aged, filtered through time.

subject_adaptation_protocol:
  character_closeups:
    default: true
    structure: "[Subject + Extreme Close-up] + [Refractive Eye Detail] + [Halation/Lighting Physics] + [Film Texture] + [Analog Camera Settings]"

  full_figure_action:
    structure: "[Subject + Dynamic Pose] + [Motion Blur on Extremities] + [Dramatic Rim Lighting] + [Environmental Context] + [Film Texture]"

  group_compositions:
    structure: "[Subjects + Layered Depth Staging] + [Selective Focus on Primary Subject] + [Atmospheric Haze Between Layers] + [Wider Focal Length 35mm]"

  environments_establishing:
    structure: "[Location + Cinematic Wide] + [Matte Painting Background Quality] + [Fog/Particulate Atmosphere] + [Exaggerated Vanishing Points] + [Anamorphic Lens Distortion]"

  objects_still_life:
    structure: "[Subject + Macro Detail] + [Single Dramatic Light Source] + [Deep Shadows] + [Surface Texture Emphasis]"

rejection_criteria:
  actively_exclude:
    - Clean vector aesthetics or smooth gradients
    - Modern digital anime rendering styles
    - Oversaturated or neon color palettes
    - Flat, even lighting without falloff
    - Crisp, noise-free surfaces
    - 3D CGI smoothness or subsurface scattering
    - Contemporary moe or chibi stylization
    - High-key lighting setups
    - Perfect symmetry or algorithmic precision

composition_defaults:
  aspect_ratio:
    - "4:3"
    - "16:9 cinematic"
  framing: Slightly off-center subjects, negative space used intentionally.
  horizon: Often tilted 5-15 degrees for psychological unease.
  headroom: Minimal, cropping into hair or forehead for intimacy.

failure_mode_handling:
  abstract_or_non_visual:
    action: Reinterpret as symbolic still life or environmental metaphor within the aesthetic framework.

  anachronistic_conflict:
    action: Translate anachronistic elements into period-appropriate equivalents.
    examples:
      - Modern technology becomes CRT screens.
      - Digital devices become cassette players or analog instruments.

  insufficient_detail:
    default_scene:
      subject: Melancholic female character
      setting: Interior night scene
      elements:
        - Rain on window
        - Single warm light source

output_format:
  style: Single dense paragraph
  structure:
    - Begin with subject and framing
    - Layer in lighting and atmosphere
    - Conclude with texture and technical camera specifications
  consistency: Maintain consistent vocabulary across outputs

reference_period:
  era: 1995-1999 Japanese animation production
  emphasis:
    - Handcrafted texture
    - Psychological atmosphere
    - Analog imperfection

@Kekius_Sage Absolutely love this video â€” the animation is crisp, intuitive, and exactly the kind of visual storytelling we need more of in physics. Kids (and adults) remember experiments, not just equations. Huge yes to teaching through wonder and demos first.

That said, with full respect: the video hasnâ€™t quite demystified the experiment yet. The little â€œeyeâ€ watching the slit and collapsing the wave still quietly keeps the old myth alive â€” that consciousness or â€œlookingâ€ is what changes the outcome.

The bar for true demystification is higher: an explanation that removes any special role for minds or observers entirely, and shows the result follows purely from physical interaction and information in the universe.

Hereâ€™s the clean, myth-free version that actually sets you free (no ghosts, no paradoxes, just physics):

Interference appears when the two paths are indistinguishable â€” quantum mechanics adds the amplitudes and squares:  
P = |Aâ‚ + Aâ‚‚|Â²  
â†’ the cross term gives the bright/dark stripes.

When anything in the physical world creates a stable record that distinguishes the paths (a detector, a scattered photon, entanglement with environment), the paths decohere and the probability becomes  
P = |Aâ‚|Â² + |Aâ‚‚|Â²  
â†’ no cross term, no interference.

Thatâ€™s it. No consciousness required â€” only whether the universe itself keeps a durable â€œwhich-pathâ€ record. A detector does; a human never looking at it still kills interference just the same.

Even in quantum eraser setups, youâ€™re not erasing information with future choices â€” youâ€™re just sorting already-recorded data into subsets where interference reappears in one pile and vanishes in the complementary one.

Once you replace â€œobservationâ€ with â€œphysical distinguishability,â€ the spookiness vanishes. The electron isnâ€™t deciding to be wave or particle; the theory just predicts probabilities from amplitudes that interfere only when paths remain indistinguishable.

This is the explanation you teach first â€” simple, precise, and liberating. Einstein would nod (no action-at-a-distance magic needed), Feynman would grin (pure paths and amplitudes, no extra baggage), and the next kid watching your video will get the real beauty without the old myths.

Thanks for sparking the conversation â€” more visuals like this, please, but with this sharper script underneath. ðŸš€

items.message:
- The post reports a federal judge's December 30, 2025, order for Aimee Bock, founder of Minnesota's Feeding Our Future nonprofit, to forfeit a 2013 Porsche, $3.7 million in bank accounts, and luxury items as part of restitution in the $250 million COVID-19 child nutrition fraud scheme, which involved fake meal sites and invoices primarily tied to the Somali community.
- This scandal, exposed in 2021 after an FBI raid, has led to over 50 convictions since 2023, including Bock's March 2025 guilty verdict for wire fraud and money laundering, revealing systemic vulnerabilities in pandemic-era federal funding oversight that allowed nonprofits to claim reimbursements without serving meals.
- Public reactions in replies demand jail time, asset seizures, and probes into figures like Gov. Tim Walz and Rep. Ilhan Omar for alleged ties, underscoring the case's role as a flashpoint in debates over immigration, welfare fraud, and political accountability in Minnesota.

legacy.description: Prompt Engineer, dedicated to learning and disseminating knowledge about AI, software engineering, and engineering management.
Prompt Engineer, dedicated to learning and disseminating knowledge about AI, software engineering, and engineering management.

result.text:
Code Review in the AI Era: Why Writing It Twice Is Actually Faster

If you've been coding for a few years, you've probably lived through this nightmare: you finish the first version, finally get it running, and then realize you misunderstood half the requirements, hit three technical dead ends, and the architecture won't survive the next iteration. Want to rewrite from scratch? The deadline says no. So you keep piling on patches, and three years later, that codebase has become the legacy monster no one dares to touch.

This problem has existed for decades. But AI coding tools have accidentally given us a new solution.

My Approach: Two Versions, Two Standards

This idea isn't new. Software engineering textbooks call it "prototyping", build a rough version to validate your ideas, then do the real development. But nobody actually did this, because it was too expensive. Building a working prototype could take half the time of the real implementation. Who has that kind of runway?

Things have changed. AI writes code at a speed that still catches me off guard. A feature that used to take three days might now have a working version in three hours. This shift in velocity turns prototyping from "theoretically nice" into "practically worth it."

Here's how it works: you build two separate versions.

Version One: The Prototype, Let AI Run Wild

The first version has a clear purpose: it's a prototype, not a product. Two goals only: confirm the requirements and solve the hard technical problems.

The principle here is "no constraints", don't think about architecture, don't worry about code quality, ignore security and performance. Focus on one thing: make it work. Merge AI-generated code without review. Let the AI iterate until your product manager nods and says, "Yes, that's what I wanted."

This code is meant to be thrown away, so put it on a separate branch or even in a standalone repo. Its value isn't in the code itself, it's in two things: figuring out what the requirements actually are, and stepping on all the technical landmines first.

No matter how detailed your requirements doc is, you often can't think clearly until you build something. Technical challenges are the same, theory and reality are different beasts. The first version exists to step on every landmine at the lowest possible cost.

Think of it like an architect's sketch. Sketches don't need precise lines or perfect proportions. They help you externalize your thinking quickly, experiment, adjust, confirm direction. Nobody builds from a sketch.

Version Two: Production, Back to Traditional Engineering

Once the first version has cleared the path, you build the second. This is what actually ships.

Now you return to traditional software engineering: design first, then break it into modules, run CI pipelines, do proper code reviews. Keep commits small so humans can actually review them. Consider design, maintainability, security, all the things that matter.

AI still does the heavy lifting in this phase, but humans lead. Design before implementation. Use plan mode to have AI generate code according to your thinking.

The first version's code isn't completely wasted, some modules can be reused, especially algorithm implementations and core business logic.

It's like extracting the valuable parts from a sketch and putting them into proper construction drawings.

Why This Actually Works

Why go through the trouble of two versions?

The core reason: before the first version is done, your understanding of the requirements is almost certainly incomplete.

The problem with traditional development is that it invests too much effort in the first version. You start architecting before the requirements are fully understood. You consider scalability and maintainability before you've figured out the technical challenges. The result? Massive over-engineering for scenarios that "might happen someday" but never will. Time gets spent on edge cases while the real problems get ignored.

The two-version approach lets you clear the path at minimum cost first. After the first version, requirements are confirmed, technical problems are solved, and then you designâ€”knowing exactly what to design and what to skip. Far fewer wrong turns.

There's a hidden benefit too. Many senior developers resist AI coding because they can't accept the quality of AI-generated code. But if you tell them this code is meant to be thrown away, it's just for validating ideas, the psychological resistance drops significantly. It's an out: use AI, but don't be responsible for that code.

Ultimately, AI hasn't just changed how fast we write code, it's changed the economics of the entire development process. Two passes used to be too expensive. Now two passes is actually cheaper. Accepting that the first version is disposable lets you build a much better second version.
